pullRequest.body:
This PR introduces `lake exe update_deprecations` that uses the cache to automatically replace deprecated declarations with the corresponding un-deprecated one.

The script handles namespacing, replacing a possibly non-fully-qualified, deprecated name with the fully-qualified non-deprecated name.

It is also possible to use
```bash
lake exe update_deprecations --mods One.Two.Three,Dd.Ee.Ff
```
to limit the scope of the replacements to the modules `One.Two.Three` and `Dd.Ee.Ff`.

This is intended to be a first step in automating updates: combining this with a linter that emits appropriate warnings, the functionality of `lake exe update_deprecations` can be extended to perform more complicated updates.

---

`+ String.replaceCheck`
`+ extend`
`+ findNamespaceMatch`
`+ getBuild`
`+ getCorrections`
`+ main`
`+ substitutions`
`+ toFile`
`+ updateDeprecations`
`+ updateDeprecationsCLI`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh short <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh <optional_commit>
```
</details>

</details>
These seem to be testing something else, no?

These are tests for an "internal function" of `UpdateDeprecations`.

They are based on the script that replaced `refine'` to `refine`, but the main function to test is still the same.
Do you think it's possible to do some more demonstrative testing in a branch that will not be merged but is for testing purposes only?

To test this, you can create a new file (say `Mathlib/test.lean`) containing
```lean
theorem not_useful (t : True) : True := t

@[deprecated not_useful] theorem True.lhish (t : True) : True := t

@[deprecated True.intro] theorem True.hish : True := .intro

open True in
example : True ∧ True := by
  refine ⟨?_, ?_⟩
  exact True.lhish hish
  exact True.hish
```
and then run
```bash
lake build Mathlib.test
lake exe update_deprecations --mods Mathlib/test.lean
```
to see the deprecations disappear.

Note that one of the deprecated declarations is missing one `True`-segment, but the script should handle this correctly.

@jcommelin, [here](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9393230408/job/25868928673?pr=13543) you can see a test.

* I added two files with deprecated lemmas to mathlib
* I modified CI to
* * first run a plain `lake build` so you can see the warning
* * then run the `lake exe update_deprecations` to fix the deprecations
* * then run again `lake build` but flagged to fail on warning.

You can see that the full CI was successful (the most relevant step is `build mathlib`, of course).

pullRequest.title: feat: automatically replace deprecations
